content.title: Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) Filters
content.definition: IVC filters are intravascular devices placed in the infrarenal inferior vena cava to prevent pulmonary embolism by trapping emboli migrating from the lower extremity or pelvic deep veins.

retrievable.description: Designed for removal after temporary indication resolves
retrievable.note: Can become permanent if left in place

relative: Massive PE with residual DVT (when anticoagulation risky)
Prophylaxis in high-risk trauma patients unable to anticoagulate
not_indicated: Alternative to anticoagulation when anticoagulation possible

placement.access: Femoral vein (most common), internal jugular vein, arm veins
placement.imaging: Fluoroscopy, IVUS, or bedside ultrasound guidance

suprarenal_placement.indications: IVC thrombus extending to renal veins, pregnancy, renal vein DVT
suprarenal_placement.risks: Renal vein thrombosis if filter occludes

retrieval.timing: As soon as temporary indication resolves (ideally within 3-6 months)
retrieval.technique: Snare capture through jugular or femoral access

surveillance.permanent_filters: Consider anticoagulation if possible to prevent thrombosis
surveillance.imaging: Abdominal radiograph, CT, or ultrasound to assess position

special_situations.pregnancy: Suprarenal placement if needed (IVC compressed by uterus)
special_situations.pediatric: Limited data, generally avoid if possible

learning_objectives: List absolute and relative indications for IVC filter placement
Explain importance of timely filter retrieval
clinical_pearls: Absolute indication: DVT/PE with contraindication to anticoagulation
Retrievable filters should be removed when indication resolves
IVC penetration occurs in up to 95% but usually asymptomatic
Position filter infrarenal below lowest renal vein
